awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Doppler-free indirect rotational spectroscopy of complex interstellar radicals
awd_abstract_narration:
Free radicals are an important component of the molecular inventory of the interstellar gas, driving chemical reactions which build up molecular complexity in space, but many interstellar radicals remain unidentified because of the lack of accurate laboratory data.  This exploratory project will develop a new instrument to measure highly precise infrared spectra of radicals postulated to be important in interstellar chemistry.  This will allow derivation of pure rotational frequencies of radicals with comparable accuracy to direct submillimeter spectroscopy, enabling their detection by radio telescopes such as the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA).  The project will train a graduate student and an undergraduate student in methods of advanced laboratory astrophysics, and it will conduct outreach centered around laser technology to local high schools.

Crabtree and his team will add magnetic-field “Zeeman” modulation to mid-infrared Noise-Immune Cavity-Enhanced Optical Heterodyne Spectroscopy (NICE-OHMS) performed in a positive column direct-current plasma discharge cell. This will yield "Doppler-free",  sharp “Lamb dip” spectra, which, when combined with calibration by laser optical frequency combs, will allow highly accurate and precise measurements of infrared rovibrational transitions of radicals generated in the plasma. While NICE-OHMS itself is well-established, the addition of Zeeman modulation for Doppler-free spectroscopy of radicals is an innovation that carries significant technical challenges. This project will develop this new capability at the proof-of-concept level to demonstrate its suitability for submillimeter astronomical observations, which require rotational rest frequencies of high-lying transitions to be determined to better than 1 MHz. Following construction and testing of equipment for Zeeman modulation, the v1 fundamental band of the ethynyl radical, CCH, will be recorded and analyzed to validate the accuracy of this method compared with direct submillimeter rotational spectroscopy.  Successful demonstration of this technique will provide a robust new method for wideband indirect rotational spectroscopy of complex radicals in the laboratory, thereby enabling their detection with ALMA and other submillimeter telescopes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Free radicals make up a class of molecules that drive chemical reactions in biological systems, in combustion, and in Earth's atmosphere. They are also hypothesized to be responsible for the formation of biologically-relevant molecules in cold, dark regions of space, where they become incorporated into comets and meteorites that impact young planets and may seed them with the raw ingredients needed for life. To "see" molecules like these in space, we rely on detecting the light that reaches Earth from these remote environments using powerful telescopes. Each molecule produces a different set of wavelengths that together serve as a unique "spectral fingerprint," allowing us to see those molecules even when they are many light-years away from Earth. However, the spectral fingerprints of radicals are very difficult to measure in the laboratory, which leaves us blind to some of the most important radicals that may be involved in the formation of biomolecules in space.


This project supported the development of a new laboratory instrument aimed at obtaining the spectral fingerprints of radicals which have never before been measured. The new instrument employs several innovative techniques to maximize its precision, accuracy, and sensitivity, and it is designed to be used with a liquid nitrogen cooled plasma to produce radicals. During the project period, the prototype version of the instrument was constructed, and its performance was tested by recording infrared spectra of the radical nitrous oxide (NO). These results showed that the new instrument is capable of making sensitive and accurate measurements, and future work will focus on further technical improvements that will suppress interfering signals from molecules which are not radicals.


The broader impacts of this work have involved the training of undergraduate and graduate student researchers on instrument design/construction, laser technology, data analysis, and scientific communication in preparation for entering the US STEM workforce. Two undergraduate participants graduated and are currently pursuing PhD degrees in chemistry, and one graduate student completed their PhD and is currently a postdoctoral researcher.
